thread.title: Countries Brits are LEAST likely to visit revealed as North Korea, Sudan and Chad
thread.title_full: Countries Brits are LEAST likely to visit revealed as North Korea, Sudan and Chad | Daily Mail Online

author: Katie Amey for MailOnline
title: Countries Brits are LEAST likely to visit revealed as North Korea, Sudan and Chad
text:
56 shares 34
View
comments
If you find seeing other Brits at your holiday destination a bit irksome, then you might want to try visiting North Korea, Sudan or Chad.
These are the countries we are most likely to avoid picking for a break, according to a new survey.
Just 0.1 per cent of the population have been to these countries, it revealed, along with Gabon, Nauru, Yemen, Ivory Coast, Papua New Guinea and Niger.
New survey has found that one of the countries that Britons are least likely to visit to be Papua New Guinea
Benin, Armenia, Guyana, Burkina Faso, Samoa, Tonga, Sierra Leone, Guinea-Bissau and El Salvador have also only been visited by 0.1 per cent of Brits, the survey by Hostelworld for its Meet The World Report claimed.
In fact, it said, almost half of the world's countries have only been seen by one per cent of Brits - that's 95 countries worldwide.
RELATED ARTICLES Previous 1 Next From glasses that cure jet lag to sand resistant beach... Tunisia's tourism prospects bleak following European travel... Vacation like a VIP: Kristen Stewart, Britney Spears and... London's iconic Lanesborough hotel set to officially reopen... Share this article Share 56 shares From all corners of the globe, the least-visited destinations are as varied as Chile, Fiji and Bangladesh.
Another location seen by only 0.2% of British adults is Mongolia - and its stunning Altai Mountains
North Korea is another destination that the survey found was visited by just 0.1% of British adults
Slightly more popular destinations, which have been visited by 0.2 per cent of UK adults, include Iraq, Azerbaijan, Mongolia and Senegal.
However, Mongolia's spectacular Altai Mountains are a must-visit, particularly in September for the country's Bayan-Olgii's Kazakh Eagle Festival, when riders in traditional costume perform hunting displays with their golden eagles.
The data was compiled from a survey of 1,000 British travellers, who were asked what countries they had visited in their lifetime.
